title: Marco Silva was very lucky to get Everton job and is failing miserably at trying to keep it
text:

I’ve yet to see what all the fuss is about with Marco Silva.

Yes, he can put out a team that on a good day can get it down, play through the lines and deliver some nice enough football.

But I’m completely underwhelmed by him and I’m still not sure what he has done to be given opportunities, good opportunities, by three of our Premier League clubs.

His Everton team has more than enough in terms of attacking ability but they are still not scoring goals, and that is why they have dropped into the bottom three.

Some of those forwards were his signings as well, and if he can’t get goals out of them or at least get them to make a difference creatively, then that’s down to him.

(Image: Getty Images)

When I look at Silva I’m reminded of a firework that goes up, bangs, and then leaves you thinking, ‘OK, now what?’ There’s no bang, bang, bang, no prolonged light show — just a little pop before the show fizzles out and dies. But that isn’t what Everton need, particularly not in a season when a place in the top six, maybe even top four, is there for the ­taking.

A lot of the chat by Everton fans on ­social media is that Silva has to go with Duncan ­Ferguson put in charge as a ­temporary ­measure.

The feeling is Big Dunc would at least put a bit of fight back into the players and hark back to the ‘Dogs of War’ while they looked for ­another manager.

I can understand that because at Hull, Watford and now Everton, Silva has been distinctly average overall.

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: REUTERS)

And what really gets my goat is that British and Irish managers have been overlooked for him. We’re a football crazy nation and with plenty of talent. But whether it has been with ­players, ­managers or coaches, we’ve all too often favoured an exotic name over one of our own.

This season the tide has turned a bit with talented youngsters hailing from these shores ­producing the goods from Chelsea to Sheffield United and now Newcastle.

And hopefully that has served as a reminder that at every level of our game and in every aspect of it there are people more than ­capable of ­bringing plenty to the table.

When Silva does walk out of English football he will go with ­several million pounds in his back pocket and my question will be, ­‘Having given our game exactly what?’

Because no one can tell me Eddie Howe wouldn’t have made a better fist of things at Everton than Silva has done if he’d have been given the job.

This isn’t to be all jingoistic about homegrown managers because at the very top Jurgen Klopp, Pep Guardiola and Jose Mourinho will always be great managers wherever they go.

But Silva isn’t in that bracket, so what is it on his CV that means he deserves to be managing Everton over someone who was born on home soil.

He is a very lucky man and if he doesn’t massively change tack and start getting results in the next month, he’ll be a goner.
description: Everton slumped to a fifth defeat of the season and dropped into the relegation zone after losing to Burnley 1-0 this weekend
